have High availability so high availability applications so you might consider business continuity a
fundamental of it being running your applications in a mode with an architectural setup that keeps them
running 24x7 that is highly fault tolerant that's at one end if you like the hot hot end of keeping your
applications running at the far right then of that continuity we have Disaster Recovery itself so about getting your
applications back or getting your data back after some unforeseen event maybe
your facilities become inaccessible because of some event in your location maybe network connections are dropped or
or severed to Data Centers and you need to recover things maybe Hardware fails
and you have some sort of problem like that and you need to recover data so disaster recovery at that end then in
the middle of that sort of spectrum is where you keep your data so there'll always be a need to back up data whether
you're running a high availability set of applications across a hot hot environment or whether you're going to
need to recover there'll always be data you need behind it and back up there sits in the
middle and it's not an All or Nothing thing so I think a common misconception around Disaster Recovery is that there's
a big switch that you pull and suddenly one data center turns off and a second starts up and fires up and takes on the
load it's not actually like that in reality you need to choose what needs to fail over and what does not um some
things will be more important to you than others and some things will still be working so a classic might be that
your internal telephony systems for your offices are working fine but a core back office system isn't so you don't need to
fail over your entire office infrastructure you just need to recover a single part of it the application that
your users are trying to use to service your customers so there'll always be pieces of the puzzle that you might want
to fail over independently from others and the trick is choosing the right strategy for those applications and
mixing and matching the approaches so that you have a coherent strategy and you're able to choose with granularity
which parts of your strategy you invoke depending upon the conditions and there's two um uh
measures that we use in Disaster Recovery to um classify the types of assets and the requirements that we put
around them and these are recovery recovery time objective and Recovery Point objective so RTO recovery time
objective is all about how quickly you need this asset to be recovered is it okay to wait a day to get this
application asset back or actually do you need it 1 minute after it's failed and then there'll be you know sliding
scale of times that's acceptable to you for a particular asset at the other end the recovery Point objective is how
fresh the data is that's behind that asset so you might have a recovery time
objective of 1 minute with zero data loss or it might be okay that you have a recovery time objective of a day with 30
minutes out of dat data and depending upon the application is going to differ and the balance that you put between RTO
and RPO will ultimately Define the technical strategy that you put behind that particular application
asset so think about applications on a a spectrum of complexity at the right then
we have these hot hot configurations with automatic failover so you might consider that sort of approach for your
custom facing transactional web applications where you have a very low tolerance to data loss and a very low
tolerance to outage these things need to be running because it's your bread and butter and where you earn money from at
the other end of the spectrum you might have some backend reporting system and that it requires a nightly output of
data for a data warehouse to drive the next days of activities in this case you've got a more relaxed recovery um
Point objective and recovery time objective as long as it comes up within say 12 hours and as long as the datas
let's say not an hour um out of date then you're okay and in between you going have different types of applic a
